results.headline: A Labor Hero’s Route to Leading a Nation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lula: Son of Brazil

results.summary_short: “Lula: Son of Brazil” is an unabashed hagiography of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, whose early life of poverty prepared him to lead the country.

results.headline: Church Choir’s Dueling Divas Come Out Singin’ and Slingin’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joyful Noise

results.summary_short: In the movie musical “Joyful Noise” Queen Latifah and Dolly Parton fight for control of a church choir — and much else — as it prepares for a singing competition.

results.headline: A Bookish Teenager and a Wild Child Grow Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Albatross

results.summary_short: In Niall MacCormick’s “Albatross,” a bookish teenage girl prepares to study at Oxford, while a wild child shows up and transforms relationships in the girl’s family.

results.headline: Nephew and Aunt, Like a Wistful Moth and an Enticing Flame

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Domain

results.summary_short: In Patric Chiha’s “Domain,” a teenager exploring his homosexuality becomes fascinated with his aunt.

results.headline: Not Quite an Honest Day’s Work

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Contraband

results.summary_short: In “Contraband,” Mark Wahlberg has to smuggle in money from Panama, but the story is upstaged by the cinematography.

results.headline: Life Triumphs in Rural England

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Robinson in Ruins

results.summary_short: Anthology Film Archives is showing a retrospective of Patrick Keiller’s work through Wednesday.

results.headline: Just a Regular Guy and Pickpocket

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Loosies

results.summary_short: In “Loosies,” directed by Michael Corrente, the main character is a working-class sort trying to get by with help from lifted wallets and watches.

results.headline: In Rome, Bending Joints but Limiting the Budget

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Devil Inside

results.summary_short: “The Devil Inside” is the latest addition to the fake, hand-shaky documentary horror subgenre.

results.headline: Angry Critters Spearhead an Ecological Battle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pom Poko

results.summary_short: In “Pom Poko” an enclave of raccoonlike creatures threatened by encroaching urban development wage a campaign of trickery at construction sites.

results.headline: Ejected From a Job With a Band, Landing Back With Mom in Queens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Roadie

results.summary_short: In “Roadie,” a film by Michael Cuesta, a middle-aged rock ’n’ roll Sherpa goes home to Forest Hills.

results.headline: Young Love as Divine, but a Perilous Insanity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norwegian Wood

results.summary_short: “Norwegian Wood,” a film adaptation of Haruki Murakami’s novel about the obsessional aspects of youthful passion.

results.headline: Lesbian Alien Looks for Love Light Years Away
results.display_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same

results.summary_short: A lonely Manhattanite and an exiled extraterrestrial find interspecies contentment in “Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same.”

results.headline: Hey, Kids, Don’t Mess With the Town Undertaker

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beneath the Darkness

results.summary_short: Four pranking teenagers go snooping around the house of a funeral director whose wife has recently died. Big mistake.

results.headline: Anger and Hate Devour a Man and His Country

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunter

results.summary_short: Iran is shown as a country of discontent and alienation in “The Hunter,” directed by and starring Rafi Pitts.

results.headline: One Search for a Body, Another for Meaning
results.display_title: Once Upon a Time In Anatolia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Once Upon a Time In Anatolia

results.summary_short: “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia,” an award winner at Cannes, directed by the Turkish filmmaker Nuri Bilge Ceylan, is both police procedural and existential meditation.

results.headline: A House Divided by Exasperation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Separation

results.summary_short: In “A Separation,” Iran’s candidate for a foreign-language Oscar, a middle-class Tehran couple’s disagreement over where and how to live leads to growing chaos.

results.headline: Polarizing Leader Fades Into the Twilight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Iron Lady

results.summary_short: “Iron Lady,” about the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, is the story of a widow and a half-abandoned mother who happened to have been one of the most powerful women of the 20th century.

results.headline: A Cold Mountain Village Where Heartbreak Is Everybody’s Business

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels Crest

results.summary_short: Gaby Dellal’s new film, “Angels Crest,” depicts the pain of a small town and a young father after a tragedy.

results.headline: A Brooklyn Girl Who’s Just Not Frilly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pariah

results.summary_short: “Pariah” is Dee Rees’s stirring coming-out story of a virginal 17-year-old African-American lesbian in a pious household in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

results.headline: A Crude, Rude Christmas Tale
results.display_title: Le Pere Noel est une Ordure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Pere Noel est une Ordure

results.summary_short: The 1982 farce “Le Père Noël Est une Ordure” presents two social-services hot-line employees who do more harm than good for their distressed clients.
